To achieve a smooth entry transition for the Entry component, you can use the fadeInFromTop animation you already defined and apply it to the loading-container class. You can also set initial states for the loading and progress to control the entry behavior of the component.

Here's the updated Entry.tsx component with the entry transition:

jsx
import React, { useEffect, useState } from "react";
import "./LoadingComponent.css";

const Entry = () => {
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true);
  const [progress, setProgress] = useState(0);
  const [displayText, setDisplayText] = useState("");

  useEffect(() => {
    const interval = setInterval(() => {
      if (progress < 100) {
        setProgress(progress + 1);
      } else {
        setLoading(false);
      }
    }, 38);

    return () => clearInterval(interval);
  }, [progress]);

  useEffect(() => {
    setLoading(true);
  }, []);

  useEffect(() => {
    if (loading) {
      if (progress <= 50) {
        setDisplayText("Why did the developer cross the road?");
      } else {
        setDisplayText("To git to the other side...");
      }
    }
  }, [progress, loading]);

  useEffect(() => {
    if (!loading) {
      const timeout = setTimeout(() => {}, 40000);

      return () => clearTimeout(timeout);
    }
  }, [loading]);

  return (
    <div className={`loading-container fade-in`}>
      {loading && (
        <p className={`question ${progress <= 50 ? "visible" : "hidden"}`}>
          {displayText}
        </p>
      )}
      <div className="loading-bar-container">
        <div
          className={`loading-bar ${loading ? "loading" : ""}`}
          style={{ width: `${progress}%` }}
        ></div>
      </div>
      {loading && <p className="percentage">{progress}%</p>}
    </div>
  );
};

export default Entry;

In this example, the entry transition will be smooth, and all the elements (loading bar, percentage, and question) will start slightly below the top of the screen and fade in with more opacity.

Additionally, I removed the unnecessary background-color: #1a1a1a; from the .loading-container in the CSS file to keep the background transparent so that you can see the underlying content. If you want to keep a dark background, you can set it globally in your app's CSS or provide a background color to a parent element wrapping the Entry component.

Great! To load a different component once the Entry component reaches 100%, you can conditionally render the new component based on the loading state. When loading is false, it means the Entry component has finished loading, so you can render the new component (let's call it TitlePage in this example).

Here's how you can do it:

  1. Create the TitlePage component:
jsx
import React from "react";

const TitlePage = () => {
  return (
    <div className="title-page">
      {/* Add your content for the TitlePage here */}
      <h1>Welcome to My Website!</h1>
      <p>This is the title page content.</p>
    </div>
  );
};

export default TitlePage;
  1. Update your App.tsx file to conditionally render the TitlePage component:
jsx
import React, { useState } from "react";
import Entry from "./components/Entry";
import TitlePage from "./components/TitlePage";
import "./App.css";

function App() {
  const [showTitlePage, setShowTitlePage] = useState(false);

  const handleEntryComplete = () => {
    setShowTitlePage(true);
  };

  return (
    <div>
      {showTitlePage ? (
        <TitlePage />
      ) : (
        <Entry onEntryComplete={handleEntryComplete} />
      )}
    </div>
  );
}

export default App;
  1. Update your Entry.tsx component to call the onEntryComplete prop once it reaches 100%:
jsx
// ... existing code ...

const Entry = ({ onEntryComplete }) => {
  // ... existing code ...

  useEffect(() => {
    if (progress >= 100) {
      setLoading(false);
      onEntryComplete();
    }
  }, [progress, onEntryComplete]);

  // ... existing code ...
};

export default Entry;

With these changes, when the Entry component finishes loading (reaches 100%), it will call the handleEntryComplete function in the App component, which will then set the showTitlePage state to true, and the TitlePage component will be rendered.

Now, the TitlePage component will appear once the Entry component has finished loading. Feel free to customize the TitlePage component with your desired content.

Yes, you can definitely achieve that effect in the Entry component. To create the animation of the GitHub logo moving over an image of a road, you can use CSS animations along with absolute positioning.

Here's how you can do it:

  1. Add the GitHub logo and the road image as separate elements inside the Entry component.

  2. Use CSS to position the GitHub logo absolutely on the left side of the screen and the road image as the background of the loading-container.

  3. Create a CSS animation to move the GitHub logo horizontally from left to right over the road image.

Here's an example of how the Entry component could look:

jsx
import React, { useEffect, useState } from "react";
import "./Entry.css"; // You can create a separate CSS file for the Entry component

const Entry = ({ onEntryComplete }) => {
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true);
  const [progress, setProgress] = useState(0);

  useEffect(() => {
    const interval = setInterval(() => {
      if (progress < 100) {
        setProgress(progress + 1);
      } else {
        setLoading(false);
        onEntryComplete();
      }
    }, 40);

    return () => clearInterval(interval);
  }, [progress, onEntryComplete]);

  const gitHubLogoStyle = {
    animation: loading ? "moveLogo 4s linear infinite" : "none",
  };

  return (
    <div className={`loading-container ${loading ? "fade-in" : "fade-out"}`}>
      <div className="road-background">
        {/* Add your road image here */}
      </div>
      {loading && (
        <img
          className="github-logo"
          src="path_to_your_github_logo.png"
          alt="GitHub Logo"
          style={gitHubLogoStyle}
        />
      )}
      <div className="loading-bar-container">
        {/* Loading bar code */}
      </div>
      {loading && <p className="percentage">{progress}%</p>}
    </div>
  );

To achieve the desired fading in from the top effect, modify the CSS and the Entry component as follows:

css
/* LoadingComponent.css */
@keyframes fadeInFromTop {
  from {
    opacity: 0;
    transform: translateY(-50px);
  }
  to {
    opacity: 1;
    transform: translateY(0);
  }
}

.loading-container {
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  height: 100vh;
  background-color: #1a1a1a;
  color: white;
  font-size: 20px;
  font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
  animation: fadeInFromTop 2s ease-in-out;
}

.loading-bar-container {
  position: relative;
  width: 700px;
  height: 20px;
  border: 1px solid #ccc;
  border-radius: 5px;
  margin: 20px;
  overflow: hidden;
}

.loading-bar {
  height: 100%;
  width: 0;
  background-color: #ccc;
}

.percentage {
  margin-top: 10px;
}

.question.visible {
  opacity: 1;
  transition: opacity 2s ease-in-out;
}

.question.hidden {
  opacity: 0;
  transition: opacity 2s ease-in-out;
}

Now, update the Entry component as follows:

jsx
import React, { useEffect, useState } from "react";
import "./LoadingComponent.css";

const Entry = () => {
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true);
  const [progress, setProgress] = useState(0);
  const [displayText, setDisplayText] = useState("");

  useEffect(() => {
    const interval = setInterval(() => {
      if (progress < 100) {
        setProgress(progress + 1);
      } else {
        setLoading(false);
      }
    }, 50);

    return () => clearInterval(interval);
  }, [progress]);

  useEffect(() => {
    setLoading(true);
  }, []);

  useEffect(() => {
    if (loading) {
      if (progress <= 50) {
        setDisplayText("Why did the developer cross the road?");
      } else {
        setDisplayText("To git to the other side...");
      }
    }
  }, [progress, loading]);

  useEffect(() => {
    if (!loading) {
      const timeout = setTimeout(() => {}, 40000);

      return () => clearTimeout(timeout);
    }
  }, [loading]);

  return (
    <div className={`loading-container ${loading ? "fade-in" : "fade-out"}`}>
      {loading && (
        <p className={`question ${progress <= 50 ? "visible" : "hidden"}`}>
          {displayText}
        </p>
      )}
      <div className="loading-bar-container">
        <div
          className={`loading-bar ${loading ? "loading" : ""}`}
          style={{ width: `${progress}%` }}
        ></div>
      </div>
      {loading && <p className="percentage">{progress}%</p>}
    </div>
  );
};

export default Entry;

With these changes, the Entry component will now smoothly fade in from the top of the screen upon initial load. The fadeInFromTop animation is applied to the loading-container class, which results in the desired effect. The rest of the component logic remains the same, maintaining the loading bar and question visibility transitions.

how do i add a png to my public fodler
1 / 1

To add a PNG image to the public folder in your React project, follow these steps:

  1. Create a new folder named images inside the public folder. You can do this by manually creating a new folder in your project directory or using the terminal/command prompt.

  2. Copy your PNG image file into the newly created images folder. You can do this by dragging and dropping the image file into the folder or using the terminal/command prompt to move the file.

  3. Make sure the image file is in the images folder inside the public directory. The path should look like public/images/your_image.png.

  4. Now, you can use this image in your components by referencing it using the public URL. In your case, you can use the GitHub logo in the Entry component like this:

jsx
import React, { useEffect, useState } from "react";
import "./LoadingComponent.css";

const Entry = () => {
  // Rest of your code...

  return (
    <div className="loading-container">
      {/* ... (previously defined JSX) */}
      {loading && (
        <img
          src={`${process.env.PUBLIC_URL}/images/github-logo.png`}
          alt="GitHub Logo"
          className={`github-logo ${progress > 50 ? "move-right" : ""}`}
        />
      )}
    </div>
  );
};

export default Entry;

By using process.env.PUBLIC_URL, React will automatically reference the correct path to your image in the public folder. Make sure the file name (github-logo.png in this case) matches the actual file name of the PNG image you added to the images folder.

With these steps, your PNG image should be accessible and usable in your React components.

i added the github png to my public folder, how do i import it?
1 / 1

In the public folder, you don't need to import the images like you do for other files in your React components. The public folder is a special folder in a Create React App project that is directly served to the client without being processed by Webpack or any other build tool.

To use the image in your React components, you can directly reference it using the public URL. The public URL is available through the process.env.PUBLIC_URL environment variable in your JavaScript code.

Here's an example of how you can use the GitHub logo image in your Entry component:

jsx
import React, { useEffect, useState } from "react";
import "./LoadingComponent.css";

const Entry = () => {
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(true);
  const [progress, setProgress] = useState(0);

  // Rest of your component code...

  return (
    <div className={`loading-container ${loading ? "fade-in" : "fade-out"}`}>
      {loading && (
        <>
          <img
            src={`${process.env.PUBLIC_URL}/github.png`}
            alt="GitHub Logo"
            className={`github-logo ${progress > 50 ? "move-right" : ""}`}
          />
          <p className={`question ${progress <= 50 ? "visible" : "hidden"}`}>
            {displayText}
          </p>
        </>
      )}
      <div className="loading-bar-container">
        <div
          className={`loading-bar ${loading ? "loading" : ""}`}
          style={{ width: `${progress}%` }}
        ></div>
      </div>
      {loading && <p className="percentage">{progress}%</p>}
    </div>
  );
};

export default Entry;

In this example, the src attribute of the <img> tag references the GitHub logo image using the process.env.PUBLIC_URL and the relative path to the image file (/github.png). Make sure that the file name (github.png in this case) matches the actual file name of the PNG image you added to the public folder.

With this setup, the image should be correctly displayed in your component.

does usenavigate not work?
1 / 1

useNavigate is not a built-in hook in React. It seems you might be referring to useHistory and useNavigate, which are hooks provided by the React Router library for navigation in React applications.

If you want to use navigation in your React app, you need to have the React Router library installed and set up in your project. Here's how you can do it:

  1. Install React Router:

You can install React Router using npm or yarn. Open your project's root directory in the terminal and run one of the following commands:

Using npm:

npm install react-router-dom

Using yarn:

csharp
yarn add react-router-dom
  1. Set up your router in App.js (or the root component):
jsx
import React from "react";
import { BrowserRouter as Router, Route, Switch } from "react-router-dom";
import Entry from "./components/Entry";
import TitlePage from "./components/TitlePage";

function App() {
  return (
    <Router>
      <Switch>
        <Route path="/" exact component={Entry} />
        <Route path="/title-page" component={TitlePage} />
      </Switch>
    </Router>
  );
}

export default App;

In the example above, we're setting up a basic router with two routes: one for the Entry component (the loading component), and another for the TitlePage component (the page you want to display after the loading is complete).

  1. Implement navigation in your Entry component:

Now, you can use the useHistory hook to navigate to the TitlePage component once the loading is complete (i.e., when progress is equal to 100). Here's how you can do it:

jsx
import React, { useEffect, useState } from "react";
import { useHistory } from "react-router-dom";
import "./LoadingComponent.css";

const Entry = () => {
  const history = useHistory();
  // Rest of your state and effect code...

  useEffect(() => {
    if (!loading) {
      // Navigation to the TitlePage component once loading is complete
      history.push("/title-page");
    }
  }, [loading, history]);

  // Rest of your component code...
};

export default Entry;

With this setup, once the loading is complete, the Entry component will navigate to the TitlePage component using the history.push("/title-page") method call.

The error you are encountering is because the useNavigate() hook is not provided by React Router's react-router-dom package. Instead, it is provided by react-router-dom's experimental version (version 6), and it is used for navigation in the context of a new routing API introduced in version 6.

To fix the error and use the correct navigation method in version 6, you should use useNavigate instead of useHistory.

Here's how you can modify your code to use useNavigate:

  1. First, ensure you have installed the correct version of react-router-dom by running:
css
npm install react-router-dom@next
  1. Next, modify your Entry component to use useNavigate:
jsx
import React, { useEffect, useState } from "react";
import { useNavigate } from "react-router-dom"; // Import useNavigate
import "./LoadingComponent.css";

const Entry = () => {
  const navigate = useNavigate(); // Use useNavigate instead of useHistory
  // Rest of your state and effect code...

  useEffect(() => {
    if (!loading) {
      // Navigation to the TitlePage component once loading is complete
      navigate("/title-page"); // Use navigate instead of history.push
    }
  }, [loading, navigate]);

  // Rest of your component code...
};

export default Entry;

Now, your code should work without any errors, and the navigation to the TitlePage component should work as expected using useNavigate.
